subject: Re: [junit] Fast and slow tests

messageBody:
I think being able to distinguish between fast and slow tests and different
kinds of tests is very useful. I can keep fast feedback cycles while
retaining high confidence levels. I can run all the unit tests related
to the area I am working on plus all the fast unit tests for the entire
codebase plus a subset of other kinds of tests that I deem useful (possibly
all the fast integration tests related to the area I am working in).
The "area I am working in" might be a module or package or some other slice
of the codebase - ideally it will be easy for me to select something close
to the relevant tests easily - so aggregating tests over packages or modules
might still be a very useful thing.

I do think distinguishing different kinds of tests is useful. There are
tests which check the environment (perhaps I would call the tableShouldExist
example below an environment test). There are some which might test your
wiring if you are using IOC (you do test drive that don't you?) and there
are others which test your system's building blocks (sometimes these are
called integration or system tests - and sometimes they overlap with
acceptance tests). If you are practising Agile then your unit tests are
your code-level documentation and specification and your system tests
are your architectural-level documentation and specification.

Paul.


Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
> Integration and unit tests are actually not mutually exclusive with fast and
> slow tests. Here is an example:
>
> @Test(groups = {"fast", "unit"})
> public void fullName() {
> Person p = new Person();
> p.setFirstName("Cedric");
> p.setLastName("Beust");
> assert "Cedric Beust".equals(p.getFullName());
> }
>
> @Test(groups = {"slow", "unit"}}
> public void verifyPi() {
> Pi pi = new Pi();
> assert pi.getDecimals(10000).equals(EXPECTED_DECIMALS);
> }
>
> @Test(groups = {"fast", "integration"})
> public void tableShouldExist() {
> // verify that a table exists
> }
>
> @Test(groups = {"slow", "integration"})
> public void insertGraphOfObjects() {
> // insert a lot of rows in the database
> }
>
> With this set up, I have all freedom to run "integration", "unit", "fast" or
> "slow" tests.
>
> This is why trying to represent test groups with packages and class names
> doesn't scale: test methods cannot belong to more than one group with that
> approach.
>
> --
> Cédric
